articles.author: Kyle Blaine, CNN
articles.title: Biden expands Trump's list of Chinese companies banned from US investment - CNN
articles.description: President Joe Biden signed an executive order Thursday banning Americans from investing in 59 Chinese firms believed to be linked to China's military, expanding an earlier Trump administration order.

articles.title: Joe Biden Blacklists 28 More Chinese Firms To Investors, Says White House - NDTV
articles.description: US President Joe Biden on Thursday expanded a blacklist of Chinese firms that are off-limits to American investors over their links to Beijing's "military-industrial complex," in a sign of Washington's continued pressure campaign against China.
articles.content:
US President Joe Biden blacklisted and barred 28 Chinese firms from American investment.

articles.author: Victoria Bekiempis
articles.title: Joe Biden outlines plan to share 80m Covid vaccine doses with world - The Guardian
articles.description: First 25m doses will be disbursed across Latin America, the Caribbean, Asia and Africa
articles.content:
Joe Biden has outlined how the US plans to share 80m Covid-19 vaccine doses with other countries, saying the first 25m doses will be disbursed across Latin America, the Caribbean, Asia and Africa.

articles.title: ‘Ring of fire’ eclipse to visit Canada on June 10 with partial view from U.S. - Washington Post
articles.description: The eclipse will occur near sunrise in North America.
articles.content: Farther north, in parts of Ontario, Quebec and Nunavut, Canada, a full ring of fire solar eclipse will be visible, a hollow sunlit circle climbing minutes after sunrise but continued travel bans prev… [+4448 chars]

articles.author: Ollie Neas
articles.title: How NZ’s new deal with Nasa could pave the way for moon mining - The Spinoff
articles.description:
The American-led Artemis Accords, signed this week by New Zealand, make a lot of the right noises. But they could lead to a more privatised, US-dominated future of space exploitation – and lunar mining. That’s a problem, writes Ollie Neas.
